reviewText:
This game isn't perfect, but no game really is.  I find the gameplay a bit slow overall, but it's a complex game with a lot going on each time you play.

Right off the start this game grabbed me.  The intro music is catchy.  The sound design is great.  The graphics are good, for what they are and what the game is, but I really like the artistic style even though the graphics aren't what most people would call spectacular.  The gameplay can seem simple at first, but it's not.  Not at all.  It's got style.  It's got good gameplay with well thought out mechanics.  It's got Gremlins and Gadgets and Goodies and Gold.  The alliteration - that's all mine.  And so's the gold.

FYI folks - though it may seem like it, this is *NOT* a collectable card game, every player draws from the same deck.  Everyone has the same options available to them, but it is a random draw.  You *ALWAYS* have 6 cards, even after you just played a card to move - you instantly draw back to 6.  Discard your whole hand?  Sure - but draw back up to 6 right away.  Does this affect your game?  Yeah, you may have been on the way to a place where you can play one of your cards, but because of the draw you don't need to go there anymore.  You may need to backtrack for several turns to get to another location where you can do something beneficial.  You may need to go somewhere closer for an even better card than you originally had.  You just don't know, but you always have options because you always have 6 cards.

The gameplay is rather deep and it takes a while to get used to it.  I've played a couple games vs the A.I. and haven't won yet, but I'm getting the hang of it.  It may take a couple more games before my plans actually start to pan out a bit better.

Yes, this is a board game and yes a 6 sided random number generator is used.  Usually, when you play a board game you roll dice to determine a andom distance your token or player or piece moves - then you have to deal with the outcome or consequences of the space where you landed or stopped.  Simple and straightforward.  This is the method used by a lot of the classic board games and there is often little to no thought or decision making involved once you land on a space.  Why did I just explain that?  You already know that, right?   Well, I explained it because Gremlins, Inc. is pretty much the opposite of that.  And that's a very, very good thing.

In this game you CHOOSE how far you're moving based on the six cards in your hand.  You can use any of them for movement, they all have a move value from 1 to 6, with 2-4 looking like they're the most common.  Instead of your movement being random and the outcome of the space you land on being fixed, the movement is chosen by you but the outcome of the spots or places you land on is frequently random, but not always.  And sometimes you can play a card or have a permanent effect that cancels or changes the outcome of the spaces where you land.  The board also has several options for where you can go and how you can get there, plus some cards bypass normal movement rules completely.  There's always choice involved in where you go and what you're trying to do instead of the game forcing you to go somewhere and often giving you no choice over what happens when you get there.  Basically - Gremlins, Inc. is the opposite of what I don't like about many traditional board games.  Sure, they can pass the time but are you really using your noggin to make decisions?  In Gremlins, Inc. you are using your noggin - or you're losing.  Big time.

There are a variety of ways to play.  I thought I had a recent game in the bag.  I had a huge income.  I got a lot of money when I passed an income square, double if I landed on it and double if I went to the bank, which usually yields zero, I was the governor so didn't have to worry about bribes/police and had a few other things going for me.  I had nearly enough of a score to win the game.  I was, however, nearly broke.  I should have had cash like crazy, but I had the least of all the players.  Still, I was in good shape, right?  I had some cards that were easy to play and would have given me the game.  Did I win?  Nope.  Some sneaky Gremlin managed to score just enough points to win before I could.  Did I pump my income just a bit too much when I should have been doing something else?  Should I have passed up the win on that last election to get some more money or move to a different location on the map?  Should I have stayed in jail instead of accepting amnesty a couple times to get out early?  No idea... but I made those decisions myself.  I didn't lose just because of a couple dice rolls.  Sure I had a few rolls go the wrong way but I chose to to to those places and those dice rolls were something I chose to let happen.  Basically I chose my fate, not the dice.  I could have avoided those places or spots but I decided to risk it out.

I mentioned jail - you *CAN* go directly to jail in some cases, but you don't just sit there rolling dice or paying a fine to get out.  Things happen while you're in there that can change the outcome of the game - and sometimes it's actually in the jailbird's favour!

If you haven't figured it out yet, I think everyone should check this one out.  And by check it out I mean buy it and play it, or at the absolute least give it a very good look and read up on it, well beyond my review, because it's a pretty solid game and quite fun overall.

Although I found the gameplay a bit slow this game deserves at least a solid 8/10. . . so I'm giving it a 9.  Why?  Because I actually liked it from the first moment the game was fully loaded up.  Usually I'm grumpy about something within seconds - whether it's poor music, a terrible tutorial or game manual, or just a craptastic user interface.  This game did all of that, and more, very well.  What do you do with people who do something well?  You give them a good frigging review, that's what.

Edited - caveat emptor - the game needs access to the internet and is designed to be played online.  Sorry for not adding that in earlier.  Single player is possible with AI, but it's meant to be a multiplayer game.  There are several ladders" for players of various skill and rank."

A single player game took me roughly an hour, and this was with me very casually reading every line of every card and getting up to make tea, etc... so really, you could probably move through a game in 30-45 minutes.

I highly recommend this game to board game lovers, steampunk enthusiasts, and strategy/card game fans.

I bought it for $9.99 in Early Access, and there is some discussion of raising the price by about 50% when it goes live... and I can tell you that this game is easily worth $14.99. So throw some money to an indie developer and pick this up.

You wont regret it!!

This game is great. The art and theming is fantastic. The cards are clever and interesting to play. There is some RNG, but when you fail it's way more hilarious than it is enraging. (Usually.)
It plays best with friends, but make sure you're good friends before you start to play. You WILL be actively dicking each other over at every turn. It works out, though--it's as entertaining to lose as it is to win! (THERE GOES HALF YOUR MONEY, ♥♥♥♥♥!)

One of my only problems with it is the game is balanced toward zero-income. By that, I mean that a lot of the cards will steadily drain your income over time unless you combat it, so the game doesn't regularly reach an endgame state where game-winning cards are easy to build. You have to nickel-and-dime (or should I say cog-and-gear?) your way to the top sometimes, and with the prevalence of cards and mechanics that can reduce your victory point total, it can be really rough to secure a point victory.

Also, while I enjoy playing this game single-player on occasion, I wouldn't call the current single-player mode great. The AI, in an attempt to be more difficult, will target you with every card it can, which normally results in it just sending you to jail and reducing your point total every chance it gets. Combine this with the fact that gameplay in singleplayer currently consists of you racing to win in a very short amount of time, and you don't have a great situation. Oh well. You don't lose the challenge for going overtime, and the challenges themselves offer new and interesting strategies to play the game by. It makes me excited for the upcoming update where they add character abilties (as free DLC!)

All in all, this is a fantastic digital board game. If you like this kind of game, definitely pick it up and swindle the gold right out of those poor sucker's--I mean, start a reputable business today!

reviewText:
Digital Board games are a dime a dozen. Or rather, digital adaptions of real board games are. There are a few that survive the translation well, (Blood Bowl which is on Steam as well, and Diplomacy¹ being the ones that comes to mind). However, an actual digital boardgame in the true sense, a boardgame created WITH digital in mind, is not so common. gremlins is one such game, and a fine example of it. Systems that wouldn't work so well on a physical boardgame are taken full advantage of here, such as 3 didgit resources (Which doens't seem a big deal, but try telling everyone to half their currency in a tabletop game, and watch as everyone has to fuss about with the Bank to get all their paper dollars in order), long term events. The game itself is of course great too, a game of deviousness, misfortune, and constant push and pull between players.

The main mechanic that exemplifies how the game takes a unique spin on things is movement. Every player has a hand of 6 cards that are replaced as they spend them. Cards have both an effect that can only be activated on certain types of spaces, and a picture of a dice. That picture is how many movement squares you can move, and thus every turn you must select a card because you either need to move a certain # of spaces, it's the one you'd least like to keep, one you activly want to discard, etc etc. Thus even the act of moving carries decisions and tradeoffs.

The developers also take full advantage of the digital nature of the game, such as making serverside updates without pushing a client side patch.


¹ Diplomacy can be played at the website WebDiplomacy, PlayDiplomacy, or on Android client Droidippy

Early Access Review

Gremlins, Inc:
~~~~~~~~~~~

Are you a strategist? Are you cunning enough to bring misfortune to others? Are you ruthless and will do anything to win? If your answers to all these questions is yes, then…..Welcome to Gremlins City!

Gremlins Inc is a strategy/board game and guess what? Yes you are a cunning Gremlin with a golden tooth! You will have to make a name for yourself in Gremlins City. The city itself is the board and has 11 locations where you can score points, with the exception of the jail, where you will not get any points at all!

At the start of the game you will be presented with a hand of 6 cards; you can choose to change a couple of cards, all the cards, or just keep what you see.

There are 3 decks of cards. The first deck has 130 cards (check out the Gremlinopedia in the game for a full description). Each card has a number (a dice if you like, 1 to 6) on the top left corner which represents how many movements you can make with it. At the bottom, it will tell you in which location you can use that card and what you can get for it. It could be gears (points) - you need these to win the game; it could be votes - during the gameplay elections will pop up and if you have the most votes you might just become the new governor of the city and be exempt from a couple of things; it could be malice - you will need these points to access the inferno deck of cards. Make sure you have plenty of money, my dear Gremlin, because some cards will cost you to use, especially the ones that have a large number of gears (points). With the Inferno deck cards, you will need malice, vote points and plenty of money to be able to use them. There are only 6 cards per game with big points attached to them. Once they are used they are gone, so be sure to grab them first! Misfortune is your last deck of cards which consists of 30 cards.  Land on one of them and guess what will happen? MISFORTUNE! MARVELLOUS (NOT)!!

Single and multiplayer (with a leader board) modes are available to you and a comprehensive tutorial to tell you how the game works.

The 2D graphics are nice and the audio is smashing (nice Jazzy music)!

Gremlins, Inc is a very impressive early access game; fun, with plenty of humour, fairly addictive and with a great deal of re-playability.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Single and multiplayer modes
-	Good content with good humour
-	Fun and easy to play
-	Nice 2D graphics
-	Great music
-	Achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	No trading cards

Fans of this genre of game will be delighted! If it your first go at this genre, you will become of fan!

9/10

reviewText:
Gremlins INC is a strategy card board game with single player and online multiplayer that provides countless hours of fun.

I'll start by saying Gremlins INC is a very good but VERY intense game which is a welcome addition to the board game genre on Steam which is lacking good titles in my opinion.
Your goal of winning is the same as most board games and seems simple but getting there is a lot harder than you'd expect.
You start with the maximum amount of cards in your hand, which is six. Every card has a dice value and an action, some also have additional costs like votes or money. You can use the cards to either move (which can be done on used on any tile) or use it's action (actions can only be played on the tile listed on the card). If you use a card to move you CANNOT use it as an action as the card will have been used so choose carefully as some cards are worth saving. Some cards also have permanent abilities that remain active after you play the card such as gaining 50g after passing certain locations which can be very helpful in the long run. All players play from the same deck as opposed to creating your own deck which adds another element of randomness to the game.

The aim of the game is to win by either reaching the set score or having the highest score at the end of the time limit or set amount of rounds. You can increase your score by playing certain cards, going to certain locations on the board and random events. Since there are a few different ways to earn skill points there is a little more freedom in the way you decide to play unlike most board games.
You'll need to collect various resources as you make your way around the board and each resource will help you in it's own way. Gold is used to pay bribes, play certain cards and activate certain tiles or locations. Votes are used to win the election and become Governor (which has it's own rewards). Malice is gained by playing certain cards or doing some negative actions to the other players. The less malice you have, the better.
Unlike most board games I find Gremlins INC very punishing but in a good way. The board is designed to make you actually think about which cards you want to play and which you want to save because one card can be the difference between a win and a loss. You can be thrown in jail one turn before you were about to play a winning card, or lose a chunk of your income from landing on a misfortune tile so having some type of strategy matters. This can, and will drive you crazy but it does make the game a lot more fun.
There are single player and multiplayer modes and even ranked for those of you who are a little more competitive. The single player includes a handful of missions to complete and will keep those of you who don't dive right into MP busy.

The graphics are wonderful though I was disappointed at the lack of animation. Despite the artwork looking really beautiful It would have been nice to have a little more going on than just words popping up and your avatar moving along. When I play an online board game I do expect it to look a little more exciting than if I physically bought one.
I LOVE LOVE LOVE the music but once again I just feel like there isn't enough of it. Other than the intro screen music there is nothing more than a little haunting background sound as you play. Fortunately neither of these things detract from the fantasic gameplay.

If you love board games then you'll want to try Gremlins INC as soon as possible. It delivers something new and fun to a genre desperately in need of good games.  I can't wait for more of my friends to buy this so I can ruin some friendships.

The longer you play this game, the more you start to appreciate its hidden depths. The board as well as the cards really are amazingly well balanced and work in perfect concert with each other! Your initial impression when watching begginner let's plays might be that it involves a lot of luck, but once you understand how to manipulate the game board and your rivals to your advantage, it's much less about luck and much more about playing your hand in the optimal way. I've put in 20 hours already and I can still see plenty of ways to up my game. Each time I play I realize amazing new ways to combo my cards and each time it becomes more apparent, how well designed this game really is.

Throwing other players under the bus and pulling off amazing card combos feels extremely rewarding and unless you hit a very unlucky streak, the downs in this game never seem that grim, especially because everyone is hit by them sooner or later.

Players naturally ganging up on the leader(s) tends to keep the race tight and interesting until the very end in most games I played. Yesterday I've pulled off an amazing comeback, where I skyrocketed from 3 points to 20 in two turns and actually won, while the other three players had 15-18 points, undoubtedly discounting me entirely, whilst backstabbing each other. Such is the power of flying under the radar and picking the perfect moment to strike - the intense rush of pulling off such a close victory feels amazing.

This game is incredibly addicting, usually I don't play board games" often (virtual or physical)

Think of Capitalist Steampunk Gremlins and what you come up with likely describes the game perfectly. This boardgame is chaotic, wacky, conniving, frantic, frenetic and frenzied. The luck of drawing random cards is involved, but don't discount skill and there are just enough tangible factors involved - like Karma, Income and Politics - to feel you're building and progressing despite an ever changing world. A single one of your opponents cards can upset everything, but managing to come up with a plan by carefully balancing the use of your cards for either movement or playing them on specific spots for value, and have that plan last the total anarchy long enough for you to execute, even in spite of your enemies' best attempts, is a massively satisfying rush.

What I like best about this game, is the mood and atmosphere it sets. The artwork is gorgeous, the attention to detail heart-felt and the little ambient noises really set the tone. If you want to experience the rush of being a conniving little greedy gremlin swaggering down the high street of  a clockwork world, clawing at straws, willing to sell your grandmother to the devil for a dime and gain even the slightest bit upward momentum at the expense of your opponents in a chaotic world where fortunes can shift in an instance, I would wholeheartedly reccomend it.

Being foiled might smart a bit and I wouldn't reccomend it to people who hate reliance on luck, but in my opinion the occasional stroke of genius where everything goes the way you planned despite it, more than makes up for that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looks complicated, but honestly pretty easy to pick up. Move around the board, play cards to get victory points, and screw over each other in the process. Don't let early access deter you from picking it up either, suprisingly polished and very fun. If you have friends that love board games it's one to consider playing with them. As far as multiplayer goes, the community seems to be fairly small currently but hopefully more pick it up for multiplayer. There is a singleplayer mode, however, and the AI seems to be decent.

The biggest con in my opinion is simply no text chat in lobbies or during play. For that alone I can not completely recommend it. If it does not bother you it is a very enjoyable game, but if you do not have friends or the likes to play with and like the social aspect of board games than possibly you might want to stay away until they include some chat function. I understand the reasons, such as fear of abuse and such as the devs have said on the forums, but I feel it is a poor reason given that it nonsensical to think you can protect everyone and make them happy.

Still, saying that, it is a thumps up from me. Good price, fun game.

reviewText:
Gremlins Inc is a fantastic game, its one of the few board games where, after a long period of playing, you don't get bored!

Whilst the game's screenshots make it seem intimidating, I can promise you the rules are simplier than you think, yet it is a difficult game to master.

And skill is actually important in this game, RNG takes a back seat to card priority, its a game where its not the cards you are dealt, but how you play them, which makes you win. Of course, RNG is a factor here, yet there are various mecahnics in place to help you cope with the odd piece of terribad RNG, even a playstyle which can somewhat accomodate Bad RNG (jail isnt that bad when you are The Don, and you never have to worry about bribes).

There is also a great deal of deception involved, you may not want to draw attention to yourself, and so dont cash in your easy cards, so you can play a game-changer later. You can also play the quiet game until you get elected governer, before steamroling the opposition.

The game and baord itself also has a great deal of detail, the ambient music changes depending on the location of the board you are in, and strangely enough, there is a great deal of immersion (odd for a board game). The card descriptions and artstyle also make this game an intriguing delight.

Of course there are downsides:
Sometimes long games can drag out simply because you set the turn times too long (although when you get good you can just use 'fast' turn times and this problem goes away)

RNG gives, other players take it away.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I originally bought this game and only played an hour just so I wouldn't go over the steam refund limit. I decided to keep the game and I am glad I did.
Gremlins Inc, is a virtual board game.
In Gremlins Inc, you can go from a pleb to a god in a few rounds, unlike monopoly in which your fate is usually determined from the beginning.

Pros:
Single player mode, which is bassicaly challenges you can't customize.
Multiplayer. in which you can play against other people but you can also set up a lobby and play agianst yourself and A.I, lobbies are fully customizable.

Cons:
I stated in my last review that the tutorial could be fleshed out a little more and that still sticks true to me, other than that, I can't think of any cons.

------

Some intersting features that differ from some table top games you may have played are:
On the board there are these spots where you have to pay bribes, if you become the governer (elections happen every X amount of round) you don't pay bribes and you can collect the bribes payed by other players (you gain infamy if you choose to take the bribe)
---

Instead of rolling dice to move on the board like in most games, your cards that you get have a specific amount of spaces you can move if you discard the card.
This creates an interesting strategy mechanic in which you have to way out your worst cards and move accordingly, in some cases you will have to give up one of your best cards if you want to move somewhere good.
---

In Gremlins Inc there is a unique punishment system that determines the fate of the game a lot.
Certain spaces and certain thing can trigger things called 'Misfortunes'
When you get a misfortune it is random and in most cases it will be something bad to you, in rare cases it can be benificial. Some cards can be played to make it so you can choose someones misfortune instead of it befalling you.

--

Overall Gremlins Inc was a great buy and I am very glad I did not refund it, if you like tabletop games and are looking for a unique exeprerience, I can't recommend this game enough.


Now I just need to find some friends that will get this so I can play it 24/7 :P

reviewText:
Basic InformationTitle: Gremlins, Inc.
Genre: Indie, Strategy
Developer: Alexey Bokulev,Sergei Klimov,Charlie Oscar Lima Tango Interactive Entertainment
Publisher: Yukitama Creative Industries
Release Date: 11 Mar, 2016

OverviewGremlins Inc is possibly one of the best strategy, card games that I have ever played. This game is in now way a COLLECTABLE card game with microtransactions. Every player starts with the same deck, therefore making the game equally fair to start off with. The gameplay itself is rather deep, and it'll take a few games to understand how to play the game properly. Although the tutorial is well done, I would suggest playing a few games against AI to get some actual experience of how to play the game properly.

GameplayOkay so let's start off by talking about the gameplay of Gremlins Inc. The gameplay itself is very relaxed and casual to play as you would expect from board games, it is also has very deep gameplay to it. You are going to need to pay full attention when you are playing a proper game, as this isn't a card/board game where you can just leave it alone while doing something else. That being said the tutorial is a massive help when it comes to helping you out with the game, although you may feel you may know everything about this game, I would suggest playing a few games against the AI to get proper experience. This is because, for me anyways, the gameplay takes some time to get used to. Also when you play online you get ranked when you finish a match which then puts you against players with the same skill level as you. I myself would of prefered to play against some of my friends, as I woudl of found it a better and delightful experience to paly against others , rather than random people with the same skill level as me. The strategy in this game is more long term planning and pays out very rewarding if you are able to achieve this long term plan. Obviously some games will turn out better than others and some of you're plans may fall into place better than others. The gameplay feels well balanced between RNG and skill, the RNG comes into play when you gamble or when you use a card to move along the board. That being said, sometime it can be wildly unpredictable and then mess up your plans that you have been planning for the last 5 or so turns. There are some really nice mechanics that other board games like this don't use making the gameplay more unique and fun to play. The variety of cards that you can get also is really nicely done, from the good to the bad cards that you can collect throughout the game, that can be played against others or played against yourself. A few flaws the gam has with this game is that it requires a constant internet connection, even if you're just playing on the tutorial or playing against the AI. I'm not sure why that is because you can play single player to sharpen up on your skills of the game. The game also lasts a fair while, the quickest game that I played was about 30 minutes, but some games can last up to a hour and a half. If you don't like playing a board game that last a fair while then I wouldn't recommend getting this game.

Art StyleGremlins Inc. has some very nice art style implemented into the game which makes it more visually appealing to play. From the detail on the board with the city details and such, from the characters themselves all looks very polished up and well detailed. There is a nice variety of characters that all seem to have the same amount of detail and work put into each of them.

Music & SoundsThe game has some pretty solid sounds and music that really fits the calming and casual type of game. Although when you have been playing it for a while I would like some different music and sounds effects as they do get repetitive to listen to. I ended up putting on my own music becuase if the repetitive music from the game.

ConclusionThis is a awesome strategy card game, with suprisingly no microtransactions and some really fun and casual gameplay. There is some very deep gamepaly, so playing the tutorial is essential to learn the basics of the game. There is a nice community on multiplayer, which means it is also active and you will always be able to find a match on mutiplayer against other people. You're going to need a constant internet connection to play this game, otherwise it kicks your from the game (yes even in single player) so if you have a dodgey internet connection then you won't be able to play the game very well.

reviewText:
TLDR;:
1. Lacks gameplay depth. Not enough options for a strategic game, too few crazy events for a fun game.
2. Feels more like a selfmoving board game than a video game.

I really liked the trailer, the music, the art, but sadly overpromising.

In the end it is just a board game with next to no cool animations one would expect from a video game. In the trailer you see moving gremlins, but they don´t in the game. Only their character token moves along the tiles. I was hoping for some crazy cards with some subtle animations which underline their crazyiness, but there are no crazy cards at all which makes the game quite boring.
I´m not sure if they wanted to make the game more strategic and that could be the reason for not introducing crazy cards, but for a strategic game it lacks depth and options. Though, I really liked the emoticons you can use in a multiplayer game.

The moving is quite simple, you have 6 cards and every card has a dice symbol, if the card is played you can move the number of dots listed. One gets a new card afterwards from the deck. If you land on a tile you can play a card that has the same symbol and it activates the described effect. Only sad thing is that the cards are quite limited, every player has cards from the same deck, it would been a lot cooler if different capitalists had some character specific cards available and this way a slightly different win strategy, but this is not the case. So it does not really matter which gremlin you play.

The governor game mechanic is in itsself quite cool, after some rounds a governor is elected, players can try to get those election points while playing the game and if they win they do not have to pay bribes if they pass bribe tiles and can confiscate bribes others had to pay for +1 evil point, but that is all to it. The governor role is not really that important to work towards reaching the most votes and usually the one that happens to have played a card with a lot of votes wins the election. So it is more based on luck to win the election. It would been more interesting if the governor could choose a game rule that applies during their mandate.
As I was talking about evil points: They are usually quite useless. It does not really matter if you have a lot of them, it seems the game mostly forgets about them. There is a card or misfortune where you have to pay a little gold for every evil points or the player with the least evil gets an additional 3 votes for an election, but besides those cards there are not any mechanics that could make them more fun. Malice/evil points just sit in your stats without making a real difference. It could really improve gameplay if the developers added more malice related events to cards. For example: A player plays a card to get win points, as the second part of the event the player with the most malice is send to prison or the player with the least malice is getting corrupted and gets a win point and +5 malice. Something along those lines could make the game a lot more worthwhile.

As it stands I can not recommend it, perhaps for a lower price, but not the current €14.99.
